title: 110_hr1605
content:
The "Merchant Mariner Credentials Improvement Act of 2007" repeals sections 7105 and 7305 of title 46, United States Code, along with related items in the analysis for chapters 71 and 73. It also addresses the duration of credentials. The Merchant Mariner's Documents and Licenses are now valid for a 5-year period and can be renewed for additional 5-year periods. Renewed documents may be issued in advance but only become effective after the previous one expires. The Merchant Mariner's Documents and Licenses are valid for a 5-year period and can be renewed for additional 5-year periods. Renewed licenses may be issued in advance but are only effective after the previous one expires. Additionally, certificates of registry issued to medical doctors or professional nurses are also valid for a 5-year period and may be renewed for additional 5-year periods. Conditioned on possession of a valid license as a medical doctor or registered nurse issued by a State, a renewed certificate of registry may be issued in advance but only becomes effective after the previous one expires. SEC. 4. PROCESSING TIME FOR DOCUMENTS.

Section 2110 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to limit the processing time for merchant mariner's documents. The Secretary cannot charge a fee if the document is not issued or the individual is not notified within 30 days of submitting a complete application.

SEC. 5. FINGERPRINTING. SEC. 5. FINGERPRINTING. The Secretary may not require fingerprinting for licenses, certificates, or documents if the individual was fingerprinted for a transportation security card. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates may extend expiring licenses, certificates of registry, and merchant mariner documents for one year to address processing backlogs. The Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard can extend expiring licenses, certificates, and mariner documents for one year to address processing backlogs. Extensions can be granted to individual seamen or a specific group, and the authority for extensions expires on June 30, 2009. The Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard has the authority to extend expiring licenses, certificates, and mariner documents for one year to address processing backlogs. The Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard can extend expiring licenses, certificates, and mariner documents for one year to address processing backlogs. Additionally, within 180 days of this Act's enactment, an interim clearance process will be developed for issuing merchant mariner documents to new seamen for offshore vessels, including checks against terrorist watch lists and drug testing. The Commandant of the Coast Guard must submit a report within 180 days of the Act's enactment to expand a streamlined evaluation program to all processing centers nationwide. The report should include proposals to simplify the application process for licenses and merchant mariner documents to reduce errors. The Coast Guard must streamline the evaluation program for all processing centers nationwide within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This includes simplifying the application process for licenses and merchant mariner documents to reduce errors. Additionally, the application form for renewals will only include questions relevant to the period since the previous application. Applicants will receive notice of their application status and can check electronically. All collected information will be stored securely in electronic format. SEC. 9. MERCHANT MARINER SHORTAGE REPORT.

The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report within 180 days addressing the shortage of merchant mariners, focusing on entry-level mariners and evaluating the potential of an educational loan program for on-the-job training.

SEC. 10. MERCHANT MARINER DOCUMENT STANDARDS. Within 270 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard must provide a plan to allow for mail-in completion of merchant mariner document applications and assess the feasibility of redesigning the document to include a biometric identifier and meet international conventions. The Secretary must provide a plan within 270 days to allow for mail-in completion of merchant mariner document applications and assess the feasibility of redesigning the document to streamline the application process for mariners.
